children.caption: The National Restaurant Association grapples with a worker uprising. (Illustration by Scott Shields)
children.alt: The National Restaurant Association grapples with a worker uprising

children.text: By
Julia Rock
View in browser
‚ÄúComrades,‚Äù said Chappell Phillips, as he grabbed the microphone, ‚Äúplease do not leave the conference. It‚Äôs all better from here.‚Äù

Phillips, an executive at the buffet restaurant chain Golden Corral, stood at a podium in the front of a hotel ballroom in Atlanta, before some one hundred restaurant executives and managers and union avoidance lawyers mingling and sipping weak coffee.

Minutes earlier, the government‚Äôs top labor watchdog had been standing at the same podium delivering the keynote speech here at the October 2022 summit of the Restaurant Law Center, the legal arm of the National Restaurant Association.

Lobbying groups often invite government officials to their conferences to curry favor or gain insight into regulatory developments. But America‚Äôs chief enforcer of federal labor law at the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) had not stuck to the proverbial script.

Instead, the agency‚Äôs general counsel Jennifer Abruzzo warned audience members that if they fired workers for union organizing, the NLRB would not only reinstate the workers, but also seek full back pay and even public apology letters.

children.text: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not nickel and diming workers,‚Äù Abruzzo told the audience, which included lawyers from Fisher Phillips, Jackson Lewis, and Littler Mendelson,
three of the biggest
union-avoidance law firms in the country.

Abruzzo‚Äôs candid reminders that the NLRB is a ‚Äúpro-worker‚Äù agency, formed in part to ‚Äúlevel the playing field between employers and workers,‚Äù contrasted sharply with presentations by other speakers at the Restaurant Legal Summit ‚Äî the 6th annual conference held by the legal arm of the notorious National Restaurant Association, referred to by critics as the ‚Äúother NRA.‚Äù This year, executives linked to Aramark, Red Lobster, McDonald‚Äôs, Auntie Anne‚Äôs, Cinnabon, Arby‚Äôs, and Dunkin‚Äô Donuts had gathered with management-side employment lawyers to plot ways to beat back a growing threat: a restive workforce demanding higher pay, better working conditions, and, increasingly, union representation.

The restaurant industry has long coordinated efforts to suppress labor costs through the NRA, a multimillion-dollar lobbying machine funded both by its restaurant members and by the fees workers pay for required food-safety classes, according to a
recent
New York Times
report.
The group has spent its war chest on lobbying campaigns to preserve a
subminimum wage
for tipped workers ‚Äî who are
disproportionately
young, women, and people of color, and
far more likely
to live in poverty than regular minimum wage workers ‚Äî and to
help
block
state
and federal
sick leave
proposals
and
minimum
wage
increases
But now, restaurant executives are on edge. Union campaigns are suddenly penetrating their industry, which employs about 10 percent of the American workforce and has one of the
lowest unionization rates
of any sector. Over the past few years, baristas have unionized nearly
280 Starbucks stores
in the face of
enormous odds
, and
dozens of other
coffee shops
and
restaurants
have followed
suit.
Presenters at the conference were fixated on this ascendant ‚Äúworkplace democracy,‚Äù as Abruzzo has
called it

, and the agenda touted presentations on ‚ÄúTop 10 Tips for Addressing Social and Political Issues in the Workplace,‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Evolving World of Labor Relations: An Organizing Re-Union.‚Äù Speakers were prepared to tackle issues from the risks of letting employees wear Black Lives Matter-branded facemasks to how to leverage environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) efforts as part of a union avoidance strategy.

Abruzzo‚Äôs speech had set the stage for an anxious couple of days. It‚Äôs why Phillips ‚Äî the immediate past-chairman of the Restaurant Law Center ‚Äî was apparently concerned that the NLRB‚Äôs general counsel might have hurt its members‚Äô feelings.
‚ÄúHang in there, don‚Äôt despair,‚Äù he said to the audience, once he‚Äôd regained control of the microphone. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to get better from here.‚Äù
‚ÄúTimes Have Changed‚Äù
‚ÄúI started out working in the restaurant industry when I was 15 years old, maybe at $3.35 an hour.‚Äù

A stocky, jovial lawyer was presenting on ‚Äúwage and hour‚Äù issues, the bread and butter of the NRA‚Äôs lobbying work, and the audience was giggling at his tales of the good old days in the restaurant industry.
The speaker,
Steve Miller
, is now a partner at the corporate law firm Fisher Phillips, which
bills itself

as ‚Äúone of the largest firms in the U.S. representing management in labor, civil rights, employee benefits and immigration law.‚Äù His starting wage of $3.35 an hour was the federal minimum wage in 1985 ‚Äî when Miller was
about 15
years old ‚Äî and is equivalent to more than $9 an hour today, adjusted for inflation, substantially more than the current federal minimum wage of $7.25.

‚ÄúA lot of the things we talk about today, the violations, are a lot of things I personally encountered growing up I really didn‚Äôt think twice about,‚Äù Miller went on. ‚ÄúBut times have changed and you can‚Äôt do things that we used to.‚Äù

He happily recounted how in the old days he was ‚Äúdoing all of this stuff that you‚Äôre not supposed to do‚Äù as a minor, like ‚Äúwalking around with big knives‚Äù and ‚Äúshoving raw sausage into a meat grinder.‚Äù

Times may have changed since Miller was a kid wielding blades, but one thing has remained the same: The century-old NRA has been fighting to govern working conditions in restaurants for far longer than Miller has been alive.

children.text: The lobbying group
was born
during a 1917 restaurant boycott over egg prices. Within a few years, the group
was organizing
to fight unions in the restaurant industry.
It‚Äôs largely
thanks to the NRA
that the federal subminimum wage for tipped workers is still $2.13 an hour, and remains the prevailing subminimum
wage in 15
states.

When COVID-19 hit the United States in 2020, political battles in the industry intensified as restaurants became even more contentious sites of clashes over public health and workers rights. Restaurant workers had
some of
the highest
COVID death
rates in the first two years of the pandemic, as their workplaces were
hotbeds
for COVID to spread as
the NRA
and its
affiliates lobbied state and local governments to keep restaurants open. Small restaurants closed en masse while large chains, like those represented by the NRA, increased their market share ‚Äî
partially thanks to
federal aid packages influenced by the NRA.
With its coffers in the
hundreds
of
millions
, the NRA and its members now
spend
huge
sums
on
lobbying
at the federal, state, and local levels. In 2021, NRA member Inspire Brands (parent company to chains including Arby‚Äôs and Dunkin‚Äô Donuts)
took credit

for halting an effort that would have raised the minimum wage to $15 an hour nationally and eliminated the subminimum tipped wage. After the first day of the conference, attendees boarded buses to the Inspire Brands headquarters in the Atlanta suburbs for drinks and appetizers.
The organization also cultivates relationships with politicians like Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) and House Majority Leader Steve Scalise (R-La.), in part by inviting them to
speak at its conferences
In the case of Abruzzo‚Äôs attendance at this legal summit, it quickly became clear ‚Äî if it hadn‚Äôt been beforehand ‚Äî that such a cozy relationship was off the table.

‚ÄúAngelo usually makes really good decisions, that was horrible,‚Äù Phillips had told the audience  after Abruzzo‚Äôs keynote, referring to Angelo Armador, executive director of the Restaurant Law Center.
Armador told
The Lever

in an email after the event, ‚ÄúI personally invited NLRB GC Jennifer Abruzzo to come and later urged her to accept our invitation. We even covered her travel costs in accordance with all of her agency's ethics rules and federal laws. I don't recall anyone saying that it was a mistake. To the contrary, we found her presentation educational and thought provoking and hope to see her at future events. I am very glad she accepted the Restaurant Law Center‚Äôs invitation.‚Äù

An NLRB spokesperson confirmed that the Restaurant Law Center reimbursed the agency for Abruzzo‚Äôs travel expenses and those of NLRB board member Marvin Kaplan, a Donald Trump appointee who also spoke at the conference.

children.caption: Restaurant workers and their supporters have been fighting for better working conditions for years. Protestors outside a Boston-area Burger King in 1989. (AP Photo/Steven Senne)

children.text: The Restaurant Law Center is currently
suing
the Biden administration over a rule regarding how much tipped workers get paid for non-tipped tasks, and the
city of New York
over a law
ending ‚Äúat-will‚Äù employment in the city‚Äôs fast food restaurants, instead requiring that fast food workers may only be fired for ‚Äújust cause.‚Äù

For wage laws already on the books, the Restaurant Law Center conference was a chance for restaurant managers to figure out how to comply with them, or at least fight lawsuits which alleged they had broken such laws.
During his presentation, Miller of Fisher Phillips brought up another threat to low labor costs for restaurants: plaintiff‚Äôs attorneys.

‚ÄúWhy is wage and hour litigation popular?‚Äù asked Miller, referring to class-action lawsuits by workers denied wages. ‚ÄúWell, [the work is] easy, right? [It‚Äôs worth] millions and millions of dollars‚Ä¶ and it‚Äôs easy to find these claims. Plaintiffs‚Äô attorneys jump on this.‚Äù
As he spoke, Miller displayed a slide with a meme of Dr. Evil from
Austin Powers
featuring the text ‚ÄúOne Hundred Billion Dollars,‚Äù as an apparent caricature of a plaintiff‚Äôs lawyer.

children.caption: Slide from a presentation by Steve Miller of Fisher Phillips.

children.text: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of gray area in wage and hour laws,‚Äù Miller said, suggesting that restaurant managers had some wiggle room. ‚ÄúSo do you go over the top, do you do the ostrich, and stick your head in the sand? You gotta find a healthy mix.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Scary, Right?‚Äù
‚Äú
The New York Times
The Wall Street Journal
, every newspaper reports on every union win‚Ä¶ when an unfair labor practice charge is filed, when there are challenges to elections,‚Äù said
Felice Ekelman
, a principal at Jackson Lewis, one of the oldest and most infamous union avoidance law firms in the country. ‚ÄúWhen did this become first page news?‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd guess who‚Äôs reading it?‚Äù replied
Laura Pierson-Scheinberg
, one of Ekelman‚Äôs Jackson Lewis colleagues, as the two sat across from each other on the main stage of the summit. ‚ÄúMy kids. Literally. I have an 18-year-old, my kids are into it.‚Äù

The two lawyers were discussing a new threat for the restaurant industry: the unexpected rise of union campaigns in workplaces that, for decades, have largely been immune from such organizing efforts.

children.caption: Police arrest a Burger King employee at an Atlanta fast food protest in 2014. (AP Photo/David Goldman)

children.text: In December 2021, Starbucks workers in Buffalo voted to unionize, setting off a nationwide organizing campaign with the backing of Workers United, an affiliate of the Service Employees International Union (SEIU). Since then, Starbucks workers have organized nearly 280 stores with Starbucks Workers United while facing a scorched-earth union busting campaign.
Jackson Lewis spokesperson Lara Hamm told
The Lever

that Apple, Amazon and Starbucks are currently clients of the firm, but that ‚ÄúJackson Lewis was not retained in recent years to represent Starbucks in matters related to union organizing or any matter before the NLRB.‚Äù
It is nearly impossible to know who is advising companies on union avoidance campaigns because Biden has
declined to
issue

a ‚Äúpersuader rule‚Äù requiring employers to disclose when they hire third parties to advise them on union campaigns. Currently, companies are only required to disclose when they‚Äôve hired outside firms that are speaking directly to employees. The firm Littler Mendelson has been representing Starbucks in responding to unfair labor practices charges at the NLRB, per public filings.
This current wave of hospitality union organizing has not been enough to halt the decades-long decline of union density in the United States, with
new data showing
that non-union job growth outpaced the uptick in union membership last year.

Still, restaurant executives are on notice. One chain in the northeast, Ekelman told the conference, was following the news of these union campaigns and reached out to her saying, ‚Äú‚ÄòWe want to get started, we want to get ahead of the curve.‚Äô‚Äù

‚ÄúBefore, I used to say‚Ä¶ ‚Äò[Unionization] isn‚Äôt a problem for you in the restaurant industry,‚Äô‚Äù said Pierson-Scheinberg. But now, she warned, ‚ÄúKids do not care about paying union dues. Two percent of pay, are you kidding me? Their Netflix costs more. They think it‚Äôs a hell of a deal.‚Äù
The ‚Äúkids,‚Äù she added, are organizing workplaces which would have previously seemed unreachable.
‚ÄúHow does Kentucky have a unionized [coffee shop]?‚Äù Pierson-Scheinberg asked. ‚ÄúThe answer is because it‚Äôs a social issue. And it‚Äôs done by the employees, not by the unions.‚Äù
It‚Äôs not just the kids. Abruzzo is attempting to use a sorely
underfunded
NLRB, which
has lost
30 percent of its staff since 2010 (although the agency did get a small funding boost in
December
) to crack down on lawlessness by employers in union elections. The agency has successfully fought to reinstate
Starbucks
and other
workers who were
fired for
union organizing.
‚ÄúJennifer Abruzzo is a very competent lawyer, very good at her job,‚Äù Pierson-Scheinberg said. ‚ÄúShe is just busting heads and changing it all up. And it‚Äôs scary, right?‚Äù
‚ÄúI Don‚Äôt Want To Be Coercive‚Äù

In 1990, a close North Carolina Senate race threatened to unseat the race-baiting Republican incumbent Jesse Helms. During the election, Michael Jordan, a North Carolina native at the peak of his professional basketball career, declined to weigh in and oppose Helms ‚Äî because, as Jordan famously told a friend, ‚ÄúRepublicans buy sneakers, too.‚Äù
This anecdote came up at the start of a presentation by
Adam Forman

, a employment attorney at the corporate firm Epstein Becker Green, and Ariane Panter, Senior Counsel for Global Labor and Employment at McDonald‚Äôs, entitled ‚ÄúTop 10 Tips for Addressing Social and Political Issues in the Workplace.‚Äù

Forman, sporting a sharp combover and a purple bowtie told the tale by way of contrasting today‚Äôs corporations ‚Äî hotbeds of political activity and the frontlines of the culture wars ‚Äî from workplaces in the 1990s.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve come a long way from that [1990] sentiment where famous people and even corporations tried to stay out of political and social issues under the theory that Republicans buy shoes too, or eat food at your restaurants as well,‚Äù Forman explained.

The injection of political and social issues into the workplace was a theme at the conference. Abruzzo, for example, had dedicated part of her keynote address to explaining that she intends to broaden the scope of the kinds of workplace behaviors which qualify as ‚Äúprotected concerted activity‚Äù ‚Äî or activity workers can partake in while legally protected against employer retaliation.

‚ÄúProtected concerted activity also is when workers advocate social justice, racial justice, economic justice,‚Äù she explained, adding that the NLRB is currently making this legal argument in multiple cases dealing with workers fired for engaging in political activity on the job.

One such case involves Whole Foods, which allegedly fired workers for wearing Black Lives Matter insignias to work after protests over the police murder of George Floyd broke out in the summer of 2020, per an
NLRB complaint

. The federal agency argued that expressing support for BLM amounts to ‚Äúprotected concerted activity,‚Äù the legal standard for which is that the issue is relevant to employees‚Äô ‚Äúmutual aid or protection.‚Äù

children.caption: Activists protest systemic racism and economic inequality during the 2020 coronavirus pandemic in Milwaukee. (AP Photo/Morry Gash)

children.text: Forman
is representing
Whole Foods in that NLRB case. One of his fellow attorneys on the case
argued before an administrative judge
that allowing workers to express support for BLM at work could make the workplace more dangerous.
Forman made a similar argument during his presentation at the conference, when he explained that allowing employees to wear their political views will provoke an already agitated clientele.

‚ÄúParticularly during COVID, where you have all of this stress and pressure and everybody‚Äôs been locked up, and [customers] go into a place, they‚Äôre already on edge about PPE and social distancing, and all that,‚Äù he said, speaking quickly and excitedly. ‚ÄúHaving a big mask in the face, or a big button, that says something that they would spend their life screaming against at the top of their lungs. [Customers are] going to engage‚Ä¶ [Employees are] not ready for that kind of interaction, not ready for these crazy customers who are going to start throwing stuff off the table and making a scene.‚Äù
There might be another explanation for the paranoia. Privately, a Whole Foods executive
told managers
that allowing workers to wear BLM insignia was ‚Äúopening the door for union activity.‚Äù
Whether or not employers are trying to restrict speech because of a concern it could lead to union efforts, Forman advised the audience not to let things get out of hand.

‚ÄúAllowing such communications in the restaurant,‚Äù he warned, ‚Äúcould turn that location into a forum for all types of political, social justice, or human rights speech, with its attendant sensitivities.‚Äù

To the extent that workplaces becoming such ‚Äúforums‚Äù is inevitable, Forman added, ‚ÄúMaybe you try to control the process, you give them a space where they can talk about the issues in a moderated, facilitated way.‚Äù He proposed holding ‚Äútown halls ‚Äî sorry,
voluntary
town halls,‚Äù to audience laughter, adding, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to be coercive.‚Äù
If employers do want to have official policies limiting worker speech without running afoul of Abruzzo, Forman blithely offered a solution.

‚ÄúIf you are worried that one of your prohibitions is too broad, you include a carve-out, a disclaimer that says, ‚ÄòNothing in this policy is meant to intended to prohibit you from engaging your Section 7 rights‚Äù ‚Äî Section 7 referring to the right of workers to engage in protected concerted activity ‚Äî ‚Äúor discussing wages, hours, and working conditions, or engaging in conduct for your mutual aid and protection,‚Äô or whatever flowery language you want to use,‚Äù he said.
‚Äú‚ÄòWe Are Good, Union Is Bad‚Äô ‚Äî Not Good, Okay?‚Äù
Jackson Lewis has a well-known and long-standing union avoidance practice. The firm, which raked in
more than half a billion dollars
in revenue in 2021, has advised large corporations including
Ikea
and more recently
museums
nonprofits
, and
universities
on their anti-union efforts. Its founders Robert Lewis and Louis Jackson got their start in the 1950s at the Labor Relations Associates of Chicago, under the direction of Nathan Shefferman, the ‚Äú
founding father
‚Äù of the union busting industry.

But Jackson Lewis principal Pierson-Scheinberg, who presented on ‚ÄúThe Evolving World of Labor Relations: An Organizing Re-Union,‚Äù may be learning some of her best lessons in union avoidance from her teenage son.

‚ÄúFunny story,‚Äù she told the audience. Her son, a high school senior, was trying to get out of writing a paper, but the only way to get out of it was to bring an outside speaker to talk to his class.
‚ÄúHe goes, ‚ÄòMom, I really think you would be cool, and I know you do this everywhere, it would be really cool if you come in. [But] you‚Äôre a union buster, so it can‚Äôt be you.‚Äô‚Äù
Laughter rang through the audience.
She continued: ‚ÄúI said to him, ‚ÄòUnion busting? I don‚Äôt union bust.‚Äô I focus on positive employee relations.‚Äù

According to Pierson-Scheinberg and her Jackson Lewis colleague on the panel, Ekelman, this current wave of worker organizing requires a different union avoidance strategy. Hurt feelings were to be avoided, and the rhetoric could not be explicit. Like Panter and Forman, they encouraged the audience to provide outlets for employee speech, but in a controlled setting.

‚ÄúThe playbook, the organizing training that you may have been having over the years, there‚Äôs still relevant pieces to it,‚Äù Pierson-Scheinberg explained. ‚ÄúBut the most important thing I don‚Äôt want you to do is go negative‚Ä¶ You have this trophy generation that wants everything light and fluffy. You need to change the mindset to the fact that you are lucky to have them come to work. You are so lucky. Thank you for coming to work today‚Ä¶ That‚Äôs the way they want to feel, that‚Äôs the way they want to be addressed.‚Äù
Such positivity can help stave off union organizing, Pierson-Scheinberg noted.
‚ÄúThe number-one reason for people going to unions is not money, it never has been, ever, it‚Äôs always been respect,‚Äù she said.

children.caption: Workers and supporters picket outside a Chicago Starbucks in 2022. (AP Photo/Charles Rex Arbogast)

children.text: According to the Jackson Lewis lawyers, this ‚Äútrophy generation‚Äù of workers has something in common with another class of people who executives are trying to appease: investors. The increasing fixation among investors on environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) and diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) is not so different from young workers concerned about social justice, they said.
‚ÄúA lot of those things can double count,‚Äù Pierson-Scheinberg said, about ‚Äúmaking work fun‚Äù and ESG issues.

‚ÄúHow many of you are under pressure from your boards or C-suite to get with an ESG program?‚Äù Ekelman asked. ‚ÄúThis is what everyone is talking about‚Ä¶ So ESG can be part of your union avoidance process. By the way, you don‚Äôt call your training ‚Äòunion avoidance‚Äô training‚Ä¶ Positive employee relations, ‚ÄòPeople First‚Äô or whatever, but let‚Äôs talk about what it really is.‚Äù

The lawyers advised the audience that engaging their employees in ‚ÄúESG‚Äù activities might make them less likely to unionize, or at least give companies positive items to talk about in a union avoidance campaign. Messaging on topics like ESG can help companies argue, in the case of a union campaign, that ‚Äúwe have all these programs in place, we are doing all these things that the union is claiming [we] aren‚Äôt,‚Äù Pierson-Scheinberg explained.

As Ekelman noted, the union avoidance language doesn‚Äôt have to be at odds with social justice branding: ‚ÄúYour position on unions, if you‚Äôre ever asked, should be consistent with your mission statement, should be consistent with your brand, should be something that your customers aren‚Äôt going to be upset with you for‚Äî‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd cancel you for‚Äî‚Äù added Pierson-Scheinberg.
‚ÄúAnd cancel you for,‚Äù agreed Ekelman. ‚ÄúSomething that if it was on social media, you wouldn‚Äôt cringe.‚Äù She gave an example: ‚Äú‚ÄòWe are good, union is bad‚Äô ‚Äî not good, okay?‚Äù

Their suggestion for combining ESG and union avoidance was not to raise workers‚Äô wages or provide better benefits, but instead to give employees opportunities to engage in social issues at work. Like Forman had advised, employee speech couldn‚Äôt reasonably ‚Äî or legally ‚Äî be stamped out completely, but it could be controlled.

The Jackson Lewis lawyers suggested that audience members engage their workers through ‚ÄúESG programs‚Äù like ‚Äúan employee team that has an impact on sustainability‚Äù or ‚Äúa community committee to talk about community engagement‚Äù and all-staff meetings where workers can give updates on what the committees are doing.
The Intercept
has reported

that both Jackson Lewis and Littler Mendelson have encouraged clients to establish ‚Äúemployee resource groups‚Äù ‚Äî affinity groups for people with marginalized identities to discuss workplace issues ‚Äî as part of a union avoidance strategy.

On the topic of ‚Äúdouble counting,‚Äù Ekelman explained, if a union petition is filed, such regular meetings can easily be turned into a key employer union avoidance tactic: captive audience meetings.
Captive audience meetings are held by employers to deliver anti-union messages to workers ahead of a union election. Abruzzo has gone on the attack against such meetings, arguing in a
memo
that compelling workers to attend them is illegal. At the conference, she reiterated her concerns about such meetings.

‚ÄúThe issue for me is not employers being able to express their views, opinions, or arguments about why, in that particular workplace, a union really doesn‚Äôt make sense,‚Äù Abruzzo had said during her keynote address. ‚ÄúMy issue is
mandating
that employees listen to anti-union rhetoric, when they have the right under Section 7 to refrain from doing so.‚Äù
She noted that employers ‚Äúpaying for their time‚Äù makes employees ‚Äúeconomically dependent,‚Äù and therefore the meetings are inherently coercive unless attendance is made explicitly voluntary.
The Jackson Lewis lawyers assured the audience that for now, captive audience meetings are fine.

‚ÄúRight now, the law is that as long as what you say during a captive audience speech is lawful, you can hold meetings with employees and expect them to attend because you‚Äôre paying for their time at the captive audience speech,‚Äù Ekelman said.
The key, said Ekelman, is acclimating workers to union avoidance tactics.

‚ÄúYou should be having ‚Äî and you don‚Äôt have to call it a captive audience speech,‚Äù Ekelman said to crowd laughter, ‚Äúyou should be meeting with your employees on a regular basis to talk about things happening in your organization, so that if and when you need to have an old-fashioned captive audience speech where you talk about third parties, you have a history of talking to your employees in these meetings‚Ä¶ the captive audience speech is not weird.‚Äù

children.text: The tactics, such as ‚Äúold-fashioned captive audience [speeches],‚Äù remain the same, with a slightly different twist to match the moment. But among the people tasked with identifying and stamping out worker upheaval and union activity, there was a strong sense over the course of the conference that a shift was underway. The American labor movement is undoubtedly continuing a decades-long trend of decline, but you wouldn‚Äôt have known it listening to corporate lawyers at the Restaurant Legal Summit attempt to convince management that they are still in control.
As Forman reminded them, ‚ÄúLost in this discussion sometimes ‚Äî and [Abruzzo‚Äôs] presentation ‚Äî it‚Äôs your company! You own it.‚Äù
